During the 1980, In the aftermath of an H-46 crashing off of Camp Lajune and the drowning deaths of a score of grunts the Marine Corps initiated egress training for all aircrew men.  Our training then was archaic compared to what is shown in this video.  No classroom training at all.  No breathing device.  No civilian instructors.  The helo dunker was a green fiberglass tube with square holes cut out for windows that was dropped in the pool with a crane and rotated one direction or the other randomly.  We wore goggles with the lenses painted black so we were essentially blind during one of the four evolutions.  If you didn’t egress successfully you repeated until you got it right.  Twenty of us were trained in two hours.  The training we got was just to check a box.  We didn’t learn much and retained less.  Today’s program seems far better.

We did this training at New River Air Station before our deployment with 22MEU. Aug 29, 1986, two weeks into our float we were off the coast of Norway for Operation Northern Wedding. We were cross decking from the USS Saipan, to the USS Raleigh on board CH-46. I was an infantry squad leader and embarked with my squad, along with all of our armory gear onboard. Before our bird could lift off the deck it collided with the second bird behind us, came by down hard, rolled off the deck into the ocean. I can only tell you it was cold, dark and sinking. I go kicked several times in the face, head, pulled, almost passed out, but made it out alive. I really don't think anything could have prepared us for that. Many dead, I have never forgot. RIP my brothers, Charlie Company 1/6 USMC CLNC.

You can hold your breath much longer than you think you can and if you follow instructions, you won’t have to hold your breath as long as you think. But the key is patience (wait for the motion to stop) and reference points ( hold on to a reference point so you know your orientation inside the helo).  That lets you know which way the exit is.  You must rotate with the helo and not let the helo rotate around you cause your exit will not be where you expect it to be.

Been there done that, scared? oh ya.  How did I deal with it?  Asked to go first and face my fear.  Listen to instructions and follow them.  We did four runs each training evolution and the last two runs were blindfolded as if it was a night ditch.  Knowledge applied properly is power.  No water up your nose (as much as that sucks) is more powerful than the will to live.  Probably the most impactful training I’ve ever done in the military, I got to the point where subsequent training evolutions became routine.  If you train like you fight you may not live but the odds will increase dramatically.  Ironically you will repeat your training on the battlefield good or bad.
I love the spiritual advice at the end. When you are in a dark place keep your references to keep your bearings and focus on getting back to the truth, until you see the light again.

First of all, in order to feel safe upside down underwater, you need to deliberately close your soft palate so that water doesn't enter your throat by any chance. Once you are confident closing your soft palate, you won't panic when water enters your sinuses because you can be sure, it's only your sinuses and you can't drown from that. If the soft palate remains open while doing this, you may get water in your throat (if your body's reflex isn't fast enough to close it) and have the urge to cough, or worse, you could get a spasm in your epiglottis, because the glottis when sensing water instantly forces itself to close to prevent you from drowning! All I wanna say is that the first thing beginners should be taught is how to consciously close their soft palate, because that grants them with a safety feeling. A lot of people have an anatomy that even results in not getting too much water up their noses at all, because closing of the soft palate creates an air lock to prevent water from going further into the sinuses. Other people can close their noses with their upper lips, and some can even equalize air pressure in their noses with exhaling just enough not to blow bubbles, but also not to get water up their sinuses (even though when doing that, they won't be able to inhale through the regulator)... If there is not regulator and inhalation is not required, then a lot of people can actually be upside down underwater without getting water up their sinuses.

I'm a Marine stationed near the east coast and a few months ago, I got my Open Water Scuba Diving Certification. I was cave diving with a group of about 6 people in a spring in Florida. We had two dive master's one at the front and one at the rear. To sum it up quickly, I ended up behind our rear dive master (He didn't keep track of me, it is what it is.) And I very quickly found myself alone 90 feet below the surface with just my flash-light and training in an underwater cave. The visibility got quite limited. It was certainly not an ideal situation to find myself in... however, you learn to stay calm and follow your instinct. I made it out of the cave and reunited with them before they surfaced.

If anyone ever finds themselves in a bad situation underwater, just remember; there is NO situation that you can't make worse by panicking. Stay calm, and follow your intuition.

I was on vacation at a pool with a waterslide. For some inexcusable reason there was no guard on or near the slide. Children were left to manage themselves.

My sister (about 8 years old) asked me (about 12) to catch her as she was nervous going into 8 feet of water. We had both done a fair amount of swimming classes by then so I knew (turned out I overestimated her skill) she could swim that depth just fine but said sure. I caught her and she panicked. As she was trying to climb on top of me I realized she wasn't gonna let me come up to breath. I felt really calm and was able to recognize my only chance was to turn swim down and surface where I could yell for help. I came up about 10 feet away from the spot and she once I cleared away was able to calm down enough and doggie paddle to the edge.

I learned valuable lessons that day about dealing with water fears and human behavior. Luckily it didn't cost one or both of us long-term in learning. I am pissed at the staff for letting us get into that situation to begin with.

When I was in the Navy, I deployed on surface ships, subs, and was aircrew. We went through similar training in Naval Aircrewman Candidate School (NACCS). This training is much more extensive. We pretty much got a lecture and then to the dunker.

All I can say is that "anticipation is worse than the event". I got to the point that I just let everyone else exit the dunker and then left. As long as you establish a point of reference, you are good to go. We would, as soon as the dunker went in the water, grab something that allows you to visualize where you are in the helo. Once you do that, the training is easy.

However, don't take that to mean that the actual event would be a piece of cake. One can only hope that this training will kick in when the actual event happens. It can save your life.

comment_text: The first time I did a BOSIET (Basic Offshore Survival Induction Escape Training), I was certainly very nervous. I got control of those nerves by simply submerging at the side of the pool before the escape and staying submerged until the last person was out. It gave me the confidence to realise I had the lung capacity to do the escape training without needing to use air from a regulator. In the end I really enjoyed doing this type of training and generally was always the last person to get out. No hurry if you know your not going to drown immediately.

I've done something like that in Scotland before commuting to North Sea oil rigs. I remember that one guy in the next seat. He was a bit too nervous, and unstrapped his harness too early while the cabin was flooding. All I knew from him was I got a strong kick into my face while the flooding cabin started tilting, and he was kicking around disoriented. Then with pressure equalized, we jettisoned the windows and pulled ourselves out of the cabin, then out of the pool, except for mister nervous. Standing on the pool side, we saw from the surface how the divers were quietly looking into the cabin. Then after a while, they went in and pulled the guy out and up to the surface. All of us had that smile : "you had only one thing to do... and now you're dead !"
I don't remember how many runs we got, quite a few, and it all felt like an amusement park honestly.

This is a great video. In the early 1970s as a USAF helicopter pilot I had orders transferring me to a unit in Hawaii while I was attending the Command and Staff College. As part of my courses I began researching helicopters ditching at sea, preparing for my own survival in  case of an emergency in my future  job. Realizing the seriousness of disorientation under water, I wrote two articles about escaping from submerged helicopters. Both articles were published in  military magazines before formal escape training as shown in this video became available. Dan Nicholson, LtCol, USAF Ret.

Destin, enjoyable video. When I went through basic flight training at NAS Pensacola in 1979, we had to extract ourselves from a forerunner of the device shown in your video, the 9D5, cleverly called the “Helo Dunker”. However, in the spirit of “when men were men”, and “when I was a boy we walked to school uphill, both ways”, the last 3 of our 4 dunks were performed blind (wearing opaque goggles), and without any supplemental oxygen. I’m not a strong swimmer, but this isn’t about swimming; it’s about controlling instinctive panic, as you found out, and like much of my training in the USN, it really worked.
We call it sea Survival training.

I worked on an offshore oil rig for 2 years. This training is often called HUET (helicopter underwater egress training). I found it incredibly fun but will be honest, the first time you do it it is a little anxiety inducing. Very fund and very unique but the training is very robust, there are divers in the water at all times, and though the rotation is actually incredibly violent (doesn’t look that way), it is a very important skill to know. The losing your bearings is a very real thing. Every time I get into a helicopter, the first thing I do is close my eyes and feel around to get tactile memory in place as the water in real life is black as night and not crystal clear. It’s actually significantly easier to do this with your eyes closed at all times. The first time the water comes up, you certainly freak out as even the cockpit is open, it feels like you’re in a locked room filling up with water as if you’re in a crazy horror movie.

Great show! I went through the same training at Lemoore NAS back in the late 80s to qualify for a joint USAF/CAF helicopter test program. At 70, I still count that as one of the hardest days of my life, but one of the best confidence builders because I know that I can most likely get out of a sinking helicopter, plane, car, boat, whatever alive. I had to do it for one time to support one program. Those folks have to recertify every couple of years. Your camera angles did a great job showing just how disorienting it is. A few things were different for me. We had no breathing devices and wore the Navy "Craniums" but no web gear, just flight suits and boots. We had to swim the width of the pool with all that on before we could enter the simulator. We also had an extra evolution where we wore blacked out swim googles for night simulation. Not using hand-over-hand reference all the way earned you a fail or additional evolution. Also we had to demonstrate pushing off forcefully away from the cabin to prevent being caught in the eddies of a real sinking helicopter and being pinned against the belly and drug down with it. The first day's training videos were pretty darn enlightening/sobering/motivating/scary.  When we finally got to fly missions over the cold water of the Santa Barbara Channel and later Lake Eire, we had to wear the AF's "poopy suit" and air crew life vest. I was just glad the helo couldn't fly as long as a C-130. Sweating in all day in a "dry suit" makes your whole body smell like dirty feet, enough to make you consider "How bad could a sinking helicopter be?" Thanks for the very vivid flashback! I feel like I need to blow my nose and breath until my heart rate comes back to normal.

I had to undergo requalifications almost biannually while flying in the Marines. On one dunking, they put blindfolds on everyone to simulate a night water entry. One of the things emphasized was to NOT kick your feet while exiting the aircraft because you were supposed to stay in contact with the person in front of you and play follow the leader by feel. I was following the one guy who couldn't remember those instructions from 2 minutes prior and wound up kicking me hard in the face! I'm kinda used to putting my own foot in my mouth, but not someone else's! :) 

Destin, if you are interested, the Navy also has the "Dilbert Dunker" trainer nearby in Pensacola which simulates a fixed wing aircraft ditching rather than a helo rollover so there is a little impact to it initially. If you watch "An Officer & a Gentleman" it is depicted in that movie. It was a simulator the set crew made but it was fairly realistic!

In Marine Corp boot camp I was terified on swim qualification day. I was a very poor swimmer. There were three parts of swin qualls that involved flying and water crash. One was being strapped in a simulated helicopter that hit the water and flipped just like your video. The second was high speed. It simulated crashing in a jet. At a speed of about 60mph you hit the water and flip. You get your barrings from the crash and get out of a small tight cockpit to unlatch a canopy to get out. The third was falling from a platform with gear attached to you and a parachute over you as if you ditched before the crash. You have to get out from under the parachute and not get tangled to surface. This was the hardest as all you want to do is go up but if you do you are trapped under the parachute. You have to swim a distance and avoid cords with a pack on your back and a rifle you can not drop or loose. I made it just fine but two recruits got tangled and almost drowned. Had it not been a similation with instructors to save them they would have drowned. They got five tries over two days and failed to become Marines. The rest of Qual was swimming distances with full combat gear, pulling someone else to safety, getting objects off the bottom of the pool, how to not get the bends and holding your breath for long periods. A terrifying and stressful day.

This is wrong 7:00 minutes in or so.... remaining inverted is more confusing... particularly in water at night. You grab the seat but then rotate out of it to upright. Why is in a typical military crash you are loaded down and heavier than water... so you will tend to sink. If you get out of the aircraft upside down and sinking you will naturally feel you are heading up when you are actually sinking down. In combat boots and even ditching the pack, if you can, you will still sink. It is very hard to swim up to the surface and it will take an almost superhuman effort.... so awareness of up and down are very important. But even the instructor gets confused talking about it here. What sucks is most often this crashes in real life happen at night.

In August of 1991 we lost a CH46 off of Wake Island.  Call sign "Sidecar 56"(From HC11 "Gunbearers" out of NAS North Island) IIRC.  Anyhoo...lost 2 pilots and 3 crew while it was out doing FCF's on a new engine.  I watched as it headed toward the ship after declaring that they needed an emergency green deck because of a high bearing temp.  As they got close to the point where they'd flare...two of the fwd rotors departed and the helo immediately went nose down into the water.  It didn't float one second.  It basically flew at full power into the ocean driving it in.  About a year later(and this was in "Guiness Book of world records in 1992 or 93) the Navy set  a world record for deep water salvage as they pulled it out from 17k feet.  That accident specifically is why they started equipping those helos with "blister" inflation bags so that when they hit the water they'd inflate long enough so that the crew could escape.  Anyone who's ever flown in a -46 knows that normally you fly with the rear open so as to get some ventilation.  But when they hit nose low, it immediately blew out the front windows and it was akin to opening up a soup can at both ends and tossing it in the water.   No survivors after the entire battle group searched for roughly 24 hours.    I've seen a couple helo accidents and if I never get into one of them again it'll be too soon!

Tip for breathing with a regulator, without a mask, underwater. Once you know when you're taking off your mask, start breathing out of your nose a millisecond before removing he mask. That will make your brain send a message telling your body to force air into your nose and plugging it. You will also be able to breathe like normal. If you're in a helicopter crash like this one, take your biggest breath, then blow out of your nose as slowly as possible. Continue to breathe out until you get your regulator.  Once you have your regulator, your brain will send a similar message to stop breathing through your nose and start breathing through your mouth. This is for anyone that can't breathe underwater.

i raced full canopy offshore powerboats and one of our requirements was to go through regular dunker training in a pool with a full simulation rig. That training saved my life, we rolled a Super Stock cat racing the St Clair River Fest and the training did its job that day.  Thats one of the things i remembered the most, being taught that once you come to rest upside down and start to asses the situation even thought you have been in the cockpit hundreds of times it is now a foreign space and nothing is where you think it is. Keeping your head together is the other thing and thats what got us out as the boat sank, we were under water for about three minutes before we could get the hatch open, had to actually wait for equalization before we could get it open so we to stay focused and on air in control. Oddly enough getting out of the boat went without a hitch but once i hit the surface i made a mistake that almost cost me my life. I inadvertently blew my regulator out of my mouth thinking all was fine but unfortunatly forgot the other thing they told us that fuel from the boats vent can blanket the surface. A bit of that fuel got to my face and i coughed a bit sucking a full lung of water in and i found myself neutrally buoyant trying to pull the cords to get my vest to inflate and gasping water in and out. Tried to put the reg back in but but could not breathe. My brain was telling me i had maybe twenty seconds of consciousness left and i better make it count. I pulled the reg out and stuffed it through the shoulder of my vest thinking our helicopter divers were moments away and if i passed out i would still be hooked to the boat and had a chance. Right about then our lead diver Cley came up underneath me having dropped in on the other side, blew his BC and we hit the surface (sorry for long post here). Having had to actually apply this type of training real world real time was something I'll never forget.  Always enjoy the videos and thanks for all the hard work and effort getting these out there.

I see a LOT of correlation between this advice and use of hallucinagens.

I've done hallucinagens enough to have seen many people lose control of their thinking and start to panic, in some cases causing physical harm to themselves or others.
This advice is KEY to remaining calm in any situation reality will throw at you...and believe me, life WILL throw these situations at you.
The trick is, knowing HOW to think because nobody gets a warning before these situations happen.
That's the point of not only preparing your body for emergencies, but equally preparing your mind to work smoothly in the midst of chaos.

If you don't exercise your mind, you will not be ready.

Back in the late 80's when we did this we didn't have respirators and the ends of the chopper had a cage blocking you from exiting any way but the actual exit. We also had blacked out goggles on. Part of this training was also jumping into water from 50', pulling yourself onto a raft under rotor wash (very difficult), and swimming under a burning body of water (fuel on fire) to get free of the wreck. You were only allowed two breaths (only one per 25') to cross the fifty feet of burning water because the intense heat in a real situation would sear your lungs fast and of course the oxygen in the air would be limited. Also, they didn't softly land you into the water lol. Dropping a few feet and hitting water, the chopper rolling, and hearing it rush in to hit you in the chest while simulating a night op emergency landing and egress will get your blood flowing. We did have two safety divers with us. The prop wash while getting onto the life raft was exhausting and easily the hardest part. I have a serious fear of drowning and a deep "respect" for sharks so this was a real fear tester for me. Semper Fi

I don't have any professional diving experience, or have ever gone through something like this. However, I can say I am confident with being underwater. When I'm in a pool, I tend to play around by letting out a lot of air from my lungs before going under (I do it where it is shallow enough to quickly re-emerge. I'm being careful), then staying at the bottom for a little while, looking up to the surface. Or with more air in my lungs and holding on to a ladder, turn myself upside down. It is interesting being underwater and seeing the surface below your feet. I can fully comprehend the disorientation one experiences in this simulation. When you're turned upside down underwater, the air in your lungs try to force you back to the surface, and it also turns you around because the air isn't balanced equally aross the body, so the upper body where your lungs are are lighter and more boyant, while your legs are less, so they sink.

Did my HUET training donkeys years ago with some overseas NESB pilots, who were newly trained oil rig pilots from a military background.  All appeared and acted very cocky, but none spoke English and relied on the interpreter for the briefing. We did the individual cage part without air, but when we did the actual dip, they kept talking, and our drop and roll appeared quicker than the video, and went down deeper.  I still remember the sheer look of terror on the face of the person in the copilot seat. It turned out the interpreter had abbreviated key things in the briefing.

That's like when I thought, "man it's a lot easier for God not to be real," and I went to my preacher. He said, "God is real. That's not up for debate. You need to anchor yourself to that, first, and for you: you need to take it moment by moment." And when he said God is real and that's not up for debate and I need to anchor myself to that, I did. And God is amazing, because decisions don't typically come to me so quickly, like that. Pretty much, never. But that did, instantly.

I previously provided tech support to a Navy school that provided the same, or at least very similar, training, also typically to Marines. While the safety divers and instructors seemed quite used to the simulated water crashes, the students definitely were not ready to be dunked initially and seemed rather nervous. That said, this is awesome training to watch, and I imagine it's awesome to take as well, which I never had reason to. Finally, you really have to respect the marines and sailors who risk their lives even in training, albeit with every reasonable safety precaution, to protect and defend their country. While I personally prefer not to interact with groups of Marines, as Marines can act a bit... special... in groups (speaking from experience, 2 amphib deployments as a sailor), I respect the heck out of y'all.

Dude thats the version for kids... We have exactly the same (METS) trainer and we have all the lay-out of our cockpit installed such as the operator console, the correct position of the emergency windows and even the correct harnesses and seat belts. Our aircraft has only one cockpit door on the LH side, 2 emergency windows and one cargo door. We have no oxygen regulators! Therefore we have to strictly follow our procedures and the order of exit since the way we train is as the worst case which could happen to us. Even including the helicopter to ditch after a successful rescue. We train such things as for example the pilot door being jammed and blocked and exiting is only possible via cross cabin through the emergency windows in the aft cabin. Which means that in the correct procedure we all wait until the airplane came to a full stop before releasing items and harnesses, then the operator opens the emergency window and gets the raft out and exists the first. Followed by the LH pilot, and then the Co Pilot on the RH cockpit seat. We always have to know where we are and therefore have to follow a "line" of reference points which we have to touch and get a hold upon, in case, the airplane is moving (again), or if we are unable to see (injuries, night ...). A close distance is kept to the person before to know when its your turn to get out. The worst position is of course the Co Pilot in this scenario as "slow" crews may need up to a minute before all are out. But here comes the best: We do that in a location where lights can be dimmed and cut so that its all done in the dark with no visual reference at all. Before the new facility had this opportunity we got goggles with blacked out glass which had the same effect. And trust me - Upside down, blind, in the worst seat - This is no joke but some serious preparation. What our instructors always told us, is that every human is able to resist the urge to take a breath for at least 1,5 to 2 minutes. In this time, no one would die if there is enough self awareness and control over your body. But if you panic - Then its just a question of seconds when you breathe in water, and just a couple more seconds until you pass out. Fighting panic is the most important. Once you understand that, you can easily hold your breath for 2 minutes in this trainer, as everyone would be able in the comfort of their homes. And then -  Its really just mind over matter. But honestly - We have to do this training once a year, and the first time is always causing... feelings... Cheers, I hope I could help a little with more details

Honestly, the worst training I ever took part in while in the Corps. I did my egress training on Camp Hansen in Okinawa Japan. Fully scuba certified, confident diver, like yourself, and this training blew my mind. Through every live fire exercise, night infiltration courses, or regular humps in the California mountains with high temps, I never felt like I was going to die until I got to this course.

Good informative video though. Most videos I seen leave a lot of the details you have in here out. Like the video about why this training is necessary right in the beginning of the class. That crew chief saved a lot of lives and he got pretty seriously injured from that accident. Like how he didn't remember drinking "red koolaide." They do an excellent job preparing us for the situation, although I prayed every helicopter ride I wouldn't need to use the training. I found myself making sure I orientated myself next to a window, not a few seats down from one.

You left out the scariest part for me; which was when they made us use the blackout goggles, with no air. I still get anxiety from that scenario. Also, good job on the muzzle awareness. Not many people will understand the importance of why the muzzle must face towards the bottom of the helicopter. Only a brief clip of it, but I seen it.

While I was a Marine Corps Infantryman, I was with Second Battalion, Third Marines (Island Warriors - E co 2/3) based out of Marine Corps Base Hawaii - KBay (in this vid). We did a lot of Air Ops on CH-46s & '53s, so we did this training every so often. It may be a little nerve-wracking at first, but it was great training. I'd choose to do this before humping my 60mm mortar across the lava rocks of PTA on the Big Island any day. I only had one instance where I thought I was going to use the training in real life: We were on a CH-46 landing on a Navy Frigate during some bad weather. A gust of wind pushed us down as a swell lifted the ship and we slammed down hard on the deck and bounced up and sideways. The pilot was able to lift us up and away quickly, probably wasn't as bad as I remember it, but I thought we were going into the drink for sure. I remember mentally going through the checklist I learned and just telling myself to watch them bubbles as if I was reciting a prayer. Good times. Haha. - Oh AND Thanks for posting, nice walk down memory lane!

I mean... I've been in boats that tipped over, and I have a mild fear of water, big fear of drowning. It's surreal. It's happened to me at least 3 times. 2 times were in water that was below 50 degrees. You have a split second that you realize you're about to go underwater, and then welcome to your new life, under the waves. Instinctually you don't breathe, first of all, one of the times I was caught underneath the boat and a tree, and I have a real hard time opening my eyes underwater. Each time it happened I allowed myself to just wait, float to the top, then in the case where I was under the boat and trees, I felt around above the water, luckily I immediately felt the boat, and was able to orient myself away from underneath everything so I could get up above water. The river is rushing so it's hard to keep your head above water for long. I reached and grabbed the life jacket that I should have already had on. That was the warm water.

The cold water is such a different story. Boat tips, you go under, you're in shock. Luckily the water was shallow enough both times for me to stand and have my head above water. In both the cases that this happened, I stood there and spent about a minute just trying to breathe. (If you've never went from being in the sun on an 80+ degree day to jumping into 40-50 degree water, it's almost impossible to explain the feeling. But, it's like you can take a thousand breaths and still feel like you haven't taken a single one.) The only reason I was stood there just trying to catch my breath though, was because I already could see the people I was with were okay. If they weren't, I don't know what I would have done. All I know for sure, is that I have no idea. In the warm water, everything was crazy. I had grabbed my life jacket, looked for my brother, finally saw his hand get above water and I grabbed his hand and put it on the boat, so he could lift his head out of the water. Once he was good, and started orienting himself and doing his own thing to fix the situation, I looked at him and said "I'm setting the boat free, I'm going to get it back to shore." I dislodged the boat from the tree it was in, held on to it, and slowly started trying to get it back to the shore. It quickly became obvious I was going to go around at least one if not two bends of the river before I made it to the shore, but a stranger that saw everything happen had swam out while I was drifting away and helped me get the boat to shore before I made it around the first bend. If that situation had happened in the cold water.... I don't know. Someone might not have made it. Always where your life jacket 100% of the time. And do what Destin said. Calm yourself. Deliberately make one small decision at a time.

I never went on a single flight the rest of my time in without checking to ensure my air bottle valve was open and ready if needed. Hands down some of the best training that will save your life.

Long ago, back in HS I had partially similar situation, just real not training.   Went into 12' of water in the pool during class diving exercise and misjudged the location of the black colored diving brick and instead went for the drain at the very center of that end of the pool.    Got confused and had no sight of the brick, tried to reach the surface and the best that I could do was pat the surface with my hands.  Could not pull myself up any further in the water.   I guess panic must have set in as I don't remember much else other than 4 futile attempts to pull up on the surface of the water like doing a chin-up on a bar or pulling yourself out on the side of a pool.   One of the swim team members went in and got me.   It turned out that the "Rescue Pole" was not long enough to quite reach the half way point across the pool let alone just beyond that point.  I now know that if I had just stopped playing patty-cake with the surface and pulled my hands to my sides and then pushed on the water I could have come right to the surface which was only a foot or two over my head.   Also learned that without my glasses, while under water I see a lot worse than is normal without them.

How do u not get water up ur nose

I've had to do this once every 2 years for the last 13 years (next year I have to do it again), I never had problems with it. But I've seen loads of guys struggle with it though... One swede had to do the exercise so many times and never managed to keep the saltwater out, he puked his guts out for hours on end... Too me it came naturally, thank God... Just stay calm, grip your seat belt to aid in navigating yourself and wait for the chopper to turn up side down or what ever it does (they never tell us which way the chopper will go, or if it will turn at all). Breathe out through your nose once you are submerged to stop water from flooding in, and breathe in through your mouth.


What always amazed me was the genuine situations they show where this has happened and the calmness of the pilot while the chopper is going down. It's just like they are reporting the weather, nothing like the movies with panicked cries of "mayday"... It's just "mayday, we are going down, this is our position" and it's so calm you would think it is a planned landing...
I was disoriented throughout this entire video. It was a weird feeling.

And we also had to wear blackout goggles, to simulate murky water. And when I say "blackout", both lenses got a double coat of Krylon! We weren't lowered in, but dropped, slammed, rolled over multiple times, then left on the bottom(upsidedown of course). Try finding a 2x3 hatch opening after that!

Definitely the hardest part for my open water was to get the sinus control for no mask rescue swim and buddy share. The best trick for me was to push the tongue all the way back and use the regulator with sharp breaths that feel like the air is also opening your tongue regulator.  Press the back of it up into the roof of your mouth and get as much air in as you can in short bursts before exhaling a little.  I did pretty well and was able to control the panic when I caught some water going through my nose.   Most fun part was the simulated and supervised no air ascent.  Got 75 yards with full gear before the instructor said it was enough.   Hope to never have to use those skills but had to share reg once.  Pretty exciting when it is over.  Very intense and critical when you're in it.

I've been through this training twice as a Navy helicopter pilot, and nobody is ever excited to go to the helo dunker. But it, along with survival school, is the best training helicopter aircrew can get. I'm curious if they gave you blackout goggles. In the trainers I've done, some of your runs have to be in total blackout, driving home the importance of having a reference point at all times.

One other point I'll make is you said the simulator is set up like the helicopters they'd be flying in. This is somewhat true, but instructors at the initial and refresher training I've done say its not to teach you how to egress a CH-53, its teaching how to solve problems under stress. You gain the muscle memory required, take a literal breath, and solve the problem of getting out of a really bad situation. Awesome video and thanks to all of the dunker instructors across the fleet.

I did this back in 2011 at Camp Lejeune. On one of the dunks I was just exiting the craft when my foot got stuck between two of the seats. I pulled hard but my big heavy Danner boot just wedged itself tighter between the seats. I pulled myself back in and unlaced my boot, slipped out of it, re-exited the plane, and swam to the surface.I was under for probably a bit less than a minute longer than everyone else. The diver told me he didn't intervene because I appeared to stay calm and oriented. I'm no tough guy; one of the best ways to avoid panic is to simply stay focused on the tasks at hand.

As a whitewater and surf kayaker and canoeist I’ve had plenty of time upside down underwater, there’s no substitute for practice. I started paddling when I was about 8, years of repeating processes and getting muscle memory for rolling boats in numerous ways and being patient underwater were lifesavers on more than one occasion. I reckon that you could throw almost any situation at me in a boat and I’d survive (well I’ve survived every one so far 😀). Anyone that can build that calm into a helicopter accident over water gets my utmost respect, that’s gonna be a high stress moment that’s way out of most people’s frame of reference or experience. Usually I can see difficult situations on rivers unfolding, it’s an environment I can read, with tons of practice and loads of miles on rivers you reduce the stress and find that getting overtaken by adrenalin or even panic becomes almost impossible, you can slow yourself down, you know that your training will kick in and you’ll control whatever you need to, you have the luxury of building up a picture of what’s around you and time to prepare. These guys don’t get that luxury, one minute you are fully kitted up and relaxing with your buddies, the next there’s a urgent and dangerous situation arriving that you have zero control over. Can’t say that’s something I fancy trying for real! In a pool, yeah that’ll be an education and I know there’s a team who will make sure I’m safe, in a flaming, dangerous and probably dark helicopter over water, maybe add in being in an area that’s not particularly friendly to me or my country? Nope, I’ll let guys and gals with bigger balls than me do that. Fair play to them, long may they stay safe!

Ever since I was young my small little town had a public pool. I started going with my parents when I was around 6 and by age 8-9 I was going alone, which wasn’t completely allowed but since I went for so long I was practically family. I was there basically every single day from noon to 8, with an hour or two break. I’m not exaggerating when I say that either, every single day with minor exceptions.  I eventually went so much that the life guards gave me quarters to help clean up after everyone left at 8. I taught myself to swim more than anything, my parents just let me be and I’m happy they did. Doing something for yourself is much more satisfying. I became a Cub Scout for quite a few years and a couple years of Boy Scouts, didn’t quite make Eagle Scouts because I just didn’t have the time. At a camp we went to 4 times a year, we had multiple days where we had two hours of swim class. There were a few rankings you could be and had to have a keychain to show what you were. I was the highest there was, along with only one other person, out of the couple hundred that were there. Being 10 or 11 at the time being better than all of the older 16-17 year olds, really boosted my confidence. Now, being 17, having my town pool shut down because they didn’t have the funding a couple years ago, really hurt. Lost a bunch of friends that I made there and lost what I feel like a piece of my life. I don’t know why I shared with you guys this story but if you did read, I just wanted to get that story out there. Haven’t talked about it in a long time and just wanted to express my love for the water.

Before I got my pilots license and on my first cross country solo in a Cessna 172, I ended up passing my airport of intended landing. When people say you panic and/or get nervous in high stress situations, it’s completely 100% true no matter how tough you are. Once I realized I had passed the airport, I got scared. Literally. Where will I land now? Should I squak the 7700 emergency code? It’s insane how quickly things can go south if you don’t control yourself. I told myself to focus and remembered my training. Deep breathes. Analyze and take action. I reset my GPS and looked around for ground reference points. I turned  around and thankfully I was only about 4 miles passed the airport. I landed safely. When I shut down the plane I was literally shaking. I became more thorough in my planning ever since. Taking a deep breathe and getting your thoughts together will save your life.

Hi Destin, Loved the video, have done the training for offshore survival and escape training, thankfully never had to use it IRL.

I feel it might be also interesting to do a video on the escape training side of things, where you're plunged into an unfamiliar surrounding i.e. a building full of randomly placed furniture/obstacles such as those in a disaster style event on board any sort of offshore vessel or platform, but you're blindfolded to simulate smoke/darkness, wearing some form of breathing apparatus and leading a crew of people/survivors through a building to safety.

I found it quite unusually natural to lead and feel my way through darkness to get a team of 8 or so people through an unknown maze i couldnt see, but what stunned me more is how your other senses, particularly touch and sound, take over to fill the massive gap that the lack of vision leaves behind.

I think it would be a fairly rewarding experience for yourself as well as an opportunity to document and share another element to the survival side of working offshore, or even translate into real world situations that can happen to anyone.

I know I might be giving advice when I’m not in the military, but I was a swimmer for some time. I remember flip turns on a wall without pushing from the wall or coming up for a breath of air. I remember that pain from the water going into my noise. There was a quick solution to it: while you’re upside down, blow a slow stream of air through your noise. This prevents water from going inside. The reason I’m giving this advice is because the primary goal is to get out of the helicopter seats and then rush out into safety. If you’re able to hold your breath till you remove yourself from those seats, you have a great shot of making the last bit of air inside your lungs last for the trip outside the helicopter.

Just my two cents.

I feel absolutely confident in and under water. I would consider that training a good afternoon entertainment.
But the danger is always there. And this over-confidence can also kill.
I learned my lesson the hard way. I went solo diving at night during a storm ( I know, it already sounds very stupid)
At some point I was grabbed by a really strong wave that pushed me towards the shore and pulled my mask off the face. The water was murky from the sand and bubbles so I couldn't see a thing (I had a flashlight on the back of my palm but it was useless in that situation). Then I had a flash memory of one large single rock that was in that area and should be really close to where the wave was throwing me to. I pushed my hands forward and split second later I hit that rock with my hands, stopping with the rock just barely touching my nose.
Since then I keep that mental picture of that rock against my face every time I feel over-confident about something.

So, Keep safe and don't tease your luck! :)

I did this same training in Pensacola back when I was still in the Marines for my aircrew training. I also had my advanced open water dive license and am an extremely strong swimmer and yes we were all nervous. Of course we all acted tough and said we werent

I went through this training as well, but it wasn't as scary because we all had to open our eyes underwater (the instructor emphasized to never ever forget that, it's the easiest way to look for the surface). It was training for offshore workers. We don't fly at night or over muddy water.

I tried getting out of that simulator with my eyes closed and ended up doing somersaults and hit the surface upside down. It's easy to lose bearings without any visual cues because getting out of sinking helicopter underwater is not unlike flying in space, you can't really rely on gravity to orient yourself.

I can imagine how difficult it is for those marines.

Just an FYI... this is standard training for anyone who works offshore as well. It's also a lot of fun. HUET (Helicopter Underwater Egress Training), BOSIET (Basic Offshore Safety Induction and Emergency Training), as well as a few others all include the helicopter flips.

When I was in high school my friends and I would go rifting in a local river.  One day it was flooded pretty good.  The Rapids were intense.   Our raft got cought in A hydraulic .  Typically they will hold you and tire you out.  The only way out is down.  I went stuck my paddle in the water in an attempt to get the raft out.  Before I could even presses what happened I was in the hydraulic.   Luckily the water pushed me to the bottom of the river.  I didn't know what was up or down.  I opened my eyes to see the world was orange and white bubbles it looked the same all around.  Then I hit a few rocks next my foot hit a big rock.  I knew this one.  With all my strength  I tried to stand into the current.  I got my head to break the surface of the water.  50' down stream.  I managed  to swim to the shore.  I was almost into the next rapid when I got out.  Even with a life jacket on I had to force my way back to the surface.  Beaten and bruised it is truly peaceful if you keep from letting the panic set in.

Few stories I've heard about people surviving in sinking car/helicopter.

Adam Savage of Myth Busters talked about his most scary incident in the series and that was when they tested if you can escape from a sinking car. I believe the car didn't even go upside down. The old used car they bought had tons of old dust/cigarettes unknown to them, so when the car sank, the visibility went to nothing in a second. He panicked and he really thought he might die. His rescue diver in the back seat was also having issues and couldn't hand over the emergency air regulator in time.

Another story I read of was a former SAS operator who in a Sea King helicopter that crashed into the ocean during the Falklands war. You should stop reading if you can't handle really cruel descriptions.




He said he was asleep when the helicopter went down. The 20 or so SAS operators in the helicopter were fighting/clawing to get out. I believe he remembers feeling boot and clawing hands of others pushing him down as they themselves were trying to get out. Very sad.

So much respect to those who face the danger in their jobs/services.

My buoy line got stuck in a rock 10 meters underwater and when I went back up and started letting go of the air I still had, I felt a hard pull and I couldn't reach the surface by just half a meter. I panicked for a second but I calmed myself and went back down with the little air I still had and disentangled the line (I forgot the knife that day). Stay calm, control yourself and you will be able to get out of many hairy situations.

I'm an aircrewman in the Marine Corps and even just watching the videos gets my blood pressure going a little bit. We have to do this every 4 years after our initial qualification and even re qualifying made me nervous lol. But I tell you what, every time when you have some sort of inflight emergency and you're flying over water you immediately start going over everything in your head. Nothing gets hair standing up on the back of your neck like that beeping of a warning alert and it's pitch black at night. It's also a sobering moment being a crew chief instructor and having to make sure your student is strapped in while he's looking at you for answers you don't have. Or better yet, having to play it cool and just smile when you have Marines in the back who have MAYBE done this training once in their life and don't remember it very well.

Marcus Aurelius Antoninus had a similar philosophy by applying Dialectics to things he feared. By taking things back down to first principles and philosophical foundations, he could put things into perspective with the truths of the world as he understood them and conquer them that way. Everyone has their personal philosophy on life and things they take to be absolute truths (even if those foundations change throughout your life), and the trick is learning to connect everything to those foundations to ground yourself.

I've worked in the oil field for many years and been through this training many times with some variations obviously, No side mounted guns or bulky vests to strip away before exiting. That being said wearing heavy steel toe work boots and most of the time a nomex jump suit that is typically at least 2 sizes too big, also I have never been in a simulator that had any air supply other then the rescue divers outside of the simulator. Regardless of the differences remaining calm is the main skill taught in these contraptions. i personally have gotten stuck on at least one flip of the 3-4 you do in the class in many of the classes I've been through. Seat belts get caught in pockets and wrapped around limbs, and the clunky boots like to wedge into everything there is. Not the best feeling when u think your free and something halts your movement halfway out the window, but calm and clear headedness can be the difference between life and death.

I really hated this training evolution when I was in the Corps. I also had a horrible time with the bubbles and water going up my nose while trying to breath with the HAPD bottles. I messed up on one of my runs and undid my seat belt early and it is just about impossible to bust the window out of the frame without being anchored in the seat by the seat belt. I kept trying until I ran out of air and had to bail out of the back.

Another interesting point to mention is that when this is performed in full combat gear, there are rifles and armored vests getting in the way of your escape sometimes. They try to mitigate that by training us to lift the rifle over our heads and then letting go of them (as they will sink to the roof of the helo and hopefully not smack someone else in the face.

One thing that isn't mentioned in the video is why we train for egressing from a submerged and inverted helicopter. Helicopters will flip upside down in the water because all of the heavy bit (engines and gearbox) are mounted on top.

Lastly, the final run is done in full gear and wearing "blackout goggles". The goggles are basically cheap shop or chemistry kit goggles that have had the inside painted black so it completely blocks all vision.

I've nearly drowned so many times I've lost count.

I have a neurological condition that causes me to suddenly get something like locked in syndrome. Can't move, not even to swallow. Maybe really tiny communication, like barely pulsing one finger.

If I'm in a position where saliva can pool in my throat, I start to drown. Fully conscious, just unable to do anything about it. The first many times were terrifying. It's happened more times than I can count.

People nearby tend to freak out at gurgling sounds. Ironically, it's the silence that's actually dangerous; gurgle means at least some airflow.

The stuff about step by step decisions, staying calm, etc. — in order to stay alive, I have to coach other people through that, with only minimal comms during, _while drowning_. My life is at stake every time, but I have to do it in a way that keeps others calm but extremely focused; if they freak out, we lose comms, and they start making mistakes.

It takes ~3 minutes until irreversible brain damage, and there's no warning, so it's on a timer. Longest it's lasted to date was 1.5 (felt like 20).

Staying grounded myself during is difficult. It's a bit dissociative in the best case.

Really hard to communicate what it's like to have gotten used to being regularly waterboarded by my own body. Terrifying, yet blasé. Has to be.

PS No, it's not curable or treatable. Please don't get into either in responses.
Sometimes I need to remind myself, "I don't know about that." Then I can learn.
That last point really is the key to getting out of any scary situation. Don't stop thinking. The moment you stop thinking and give in to panic is the moment you lose control over the situation.

Cool video. I took a trip in 95 to visit one of the offshore platforms in the North Sea. It was an hour long visit, but I was required by BP to complete a survival course in Aberdeen Scotland prior to the helicopter flight to the platform. The two day survival course included being strapped into a mock up helicopter body dropped into a pool and rolled upside down. We had to unharness and exit the chopper and make our way to the surface on one breath of air. It was exciting to say the least. I love scuba and snorkeling so it wasn't as scary to me as to some of the other trainees, but when the chopper dropped I did begin to wonder what I had gotten inot. Hadn't thought about it for years until I watched your video.

The first time I went surfing, I had just driven 3 days by myself across the country. I went to a surf shop and picked up a board. After some exhausting minutes learning stuff, I finally grabed a wave. It was a little bigger than I first though and it sent me flying forward into the water.  It absolutely crushed me, shot me down to the bottom, and I remember my leg touching some rocks as I tumbled. The leash on the my ankle pulled my leg in the direction the board was headed and I had no idea where I was. There was no "up". Panic set in as I didn't have a chance to get a real breath before I entered the water. I didn't know where I was. I didn't know how to surface, I thought I was going to drown. Then suddenly I had this moment of clarity. I just told myself to sit still at the bottom, be calm, wait. I remember opening my eyes and looking up at the massive crashing wave above me, but where I was it was calm and quiet. I told myself I wasn't going to run out of breath immediately, so I took a moment to figure out the situation.  I just relaxed and waited for everything to pass. I looked around again, the water above was calm. I swam up, grabbed my board, and headed for shore. I still think of this moment when I get overwhelmed by stuff. How I was able to just sit back and analyze the situation. This was one of the scariest moments of my life while I was entering the water, only to turn into one of the calmest I can remember to this day.

In software engineering (my field), a customer can have a serious problem with your software that can result in a need to come up with a solution under pressure (perhaps within minutes, to include how to get the solution to the customer, and how to implement the solution without side effects). The customer could be in media broadcasting with crazy always-running requirements, or a hospital with life-and-death consequences, or NASA with similar concerns, or even something as simple as a demonstration of the new, not-quite-fully-vetted bleeding-edge code in front of super-important customers when something catastrophically awful happens and you have to recover.

In such situations, you have to think through the problem. The calm person who ignores the pressure to focus on solving the problem while not even breaking a sweat wins in these scenarios. While everyone else is screaming, be the calmest person in the room, focus on the problem, and fix it.

You'll get mad respect for it.

In a career that spanned over 30 years working in the Gulf of Mexico on oil rigs, I've had to endure 5 different HUET training sessions over the years. I've personally known 5 people killed in helicopter crashes and only one that's survived a water "landing". I've always looked at the HUET training as a day off of work playing in the pool, because your chances of surviving a water crash landing of a helicopter are fairly slim.  Working on an offshore oil installation usually isn't much safer. You're working or housed within a hundred feet or so of highly pressurized, extremely flammable materials that are only a heart beat away from escaping their confines and making for a real bad day. When its time to run, there is no place to run, no safe place to hide....

I went through the "Dunker" in 1995 at Naval Air Station Pensacola as part of my USAF Helicopter Flight Engineer Training.  We weren't fortunate enough to even have respirators and emergency oxygen available to us.  We did it four different times.  Once going out the nearest exit, once going out the main cabin exit and then the same exits but wearing blacked out goggles.  I'm a decent swimmer and don't have to hold my nose when I go under.  I thoroughly enjoyed that training.  A couple of years later I had to certify with a 10 minute emergency air bottle with a mouth piece.  That part I didn't find as fun to do.

Great video. I have taken the Helicopter Escape Course for the Gulf of Mexico once in Morgan City and another time in another city(I forget),  in Aberdeen and in Singapore. The Singapore course was the best. There the divers have to take it with blackout goggles. I had already passed the first go round and was not required to use the blackout goggles but volunteered anyway because I was curious and also because it would give a chance to embarrass the divers or myself. We asked the instructor what was the single most important thing we could do to increase our chances for survival. He said wait to board at the heliport and be the closest one to the door. hat way you don't have to rely on someone else not panicking. Survival first depends on the decision to survive and then doing those things needed to survive including not following instructions that would hinder it. In the Piper Alpha disaster in the North Sea the only survivors were the ones who ignored instructions to remain in the Crews Mess.
